tutorial.title: Travel Blog
tutorial.descriptionContent: Use Semantic HTML to create a Travel Blog

executableContent.instructions:
Inspired by a travel destination website, you've decided to try out your hands at semantic HTML and create a travel blog.

Take a look at this boilerplate we've provided for you. You can see we already have a `title` and `link` element. We'll use the `title` and `link` elements later, but for now, you don't need to worry about them. We also already have a `body` and `h1` element. You'll see the `h1` text in the preview.

1. Look at the code and make sure you understand everything used.
2. Move to the next lesson.

We want to display the navigation in the header. We also want to display the navigation name. We'll use semantic HTML for the `header` and `nav` elements. The navigation title should stand out so we'll use an `h2` element.

1. Code a `header` element directly beneath the `h1` element.
2. Code a `nav` element inside the ` header` element.
3. Code an `h2` element inside the `nav` element with the heading `Menu`.

We want to have links inside of our navigation menu. For the menu, we'll want the links to be on separate lines.

1. Code an `a` element directly under the `h2` element. Give an `href` attribute with value of `"#"` and the text `Latest Post`.  Add a line break element.
2. Code an `a` element directly under the previous `a` element. Give an `href` attribute with a value of the hash `#` and the string `Favorite Pictures`.  Add a line break element.
3. Code an `a` element directly under the previous `a` element. Give an `href` attribute with a value of the hash `#` and the string `Contact`.

files.name: index.html
files.solvedContent:
Travel Blog

Menu

Latest Post
Favorite Pictures
Contact

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
- You can create a line break element with the tag `
`.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's add the dominant content of the blog. We'll use a `main` element to make this content semantic, and give it a title. The title should stand out so we'll use an `h2` element.

1. Code a `main` element directly underneath the closing tag of the `header`.
2. Code an `h2` element directly inside the ` main` element. Give it the string `Traveling the World`.

Contact

executableContent.instructions:
Let's add a `section` element. We want the section to have a title. We also want to add a `detail` element inside of the section. 

1. Code a `section` element directly under the `h2` element.
2. Code an `h3` element inside of the `section` element. Give it the string `Latest Post`.
3. Code a `details` element directly under the `h3` element.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's add a summary inside of the `details` element. We'll also add some basic details after the summary.

1. Code a `summary` element inside the `details` element and give it the string `Rio's Beaches`.
2. Code a `p` element directly under the `summary` element and give it the string `Where: Rio de Janeiro, BR`. Make sure to add `BR`, which stands for Brazil. 
3. Code a `p` element directly under the previous `p` element and give it the string `Time Since Post: 5D` .
4. Code a `p` element directly under the previous `p` element and give it the string `Rio is full of world class beaches...`.

executableContent.instructions:
We want to give clarity to the abbreviation and time that we used in the `p` elements.

1. Code `abbr` tags around the string `BR` in the first `p` element.
2. Code `time` tags around the string `5D` in the second `p` element.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's add some images. We want these images and their descriptions to be clearly identified in the HTML. 

1. Code two `figure` elements directly after the `h3` element.
2. Code an `img` element inside each `figure` element.
3. Code a `figcaption` element directly after each `img` element.
4. Give a `src` attribute to the first `img` element with the string `"https://mimo.app/i/colosseum.png"`. Give the `figcaption` element the string `Rome`.
5. Give a `src` attribute to the second `img` element with the string `"https://mimo.app/i/eiffel.png"`. Give the `figcaption` element the string `Paris`.
6. Give both `img` elements a `width` attribute with the string `150px`.

executableContent.instructions:
We want to add a footer at the bottom of the page. Our footer will contain contact information for the blog.

1. Code a `footer` element directly under the closing tag of the `main` element.
2. Code a `p` element inside the `footer` element. Give it the string `Contact:`.
3. Code a `button` element directly under the `p` element. Give it the string `Instagram`.
4. Code a second `button` element directly under the first `button` element. Give it the string `Twitter`.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's finish the footer by adding an address. 

1. Code an `address` element directly after the second button element.
2. Give the `address` element the string `500 Wandering Lane, Houston, TX 77573`.
3. Make sure to code `abbr` tags around `TX` , which stands for Texas.
